properties.name: Jaguar Habitat in Mirador
properties.description: Jaguar Study 2007 (Mirador Basin)Jaguar Habitat in the MiradorMirador in northern Guatemala comprises one of the last large intact humid rainforests left in Central America -600,000 acres in the heart of the Maya Biosphere Reserve. Mirador's natural habitats provide one of the last biodiversity sanctuaries for over 40 threatened wildlife species, 200 native and migratory birds, 300 species of trees and 2,000 different flora. In May of 2007, the Wildlife Conservation Society's team, lead by Roan McNab, and funded by FARES and GHF, conducted the first biological study ever conducted in this area. A network of infrared, motion-detection cameras was set up to capture wildlife and in particular Jaguars, roaming within the southern portion of Mirador Basin , known as La Gloria Logging Concession. This photo tour link shows film developed late May, 2007 and are the first ever photos of these endangered species taken within this region.Threats to the JaguarToday, more than 65% of the jaguar's habitat in Mexico and Central America has already been lost. According to the World Wildlife Foundation, over the past 10 years, destruction of the Maya Biosphere Reserve in Guatemala has left only 36% of its native tropical rainforests still intact. Habitat loss, mostly through rampant logging, deforestation and poaching, is by far the greatest threat to Mirador's biodiversity and is creating an 'Empty Forest'. Click here to view Jaguar Study Photo GalleryLearn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: El Mirador
properties.description: El MiradorEl Mirador, "The Lookout"El Mirador is the largest known site of the Preclassic Maya era. The largest architectural works of the entire Preclassic perieod are found here. Buildings the size of La Danta, El Tigre, and Monos were never reproduced in Maya history.Learn more about MiradorFly closer: 3D-models & 5 points of interestFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: El Tigre Pyramid
properties.description: Mirador: El TigreView 3D model of El TigreSee the entire GHF model collection at the 3D WarehouseEl Tigre pyramid is one of the largest pyramids in El Mirador and is exactly 200 meters from La Danta on a perfect parallel axis.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Stucco Mask
properties.description: Mirador: Structure 34Stucco mask and jaguar paw flank the steps of Structure 34. The jaguar paw and steps have been covered with a protective layer of stucco.The upper section of Structure 34 is the most thoroughly investigated building at El Mirador. Click here to explore interactive QuickTime VR 360 panorama of Structure 34Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Summit of La Danta Pyramid
properties.description: Mirador: La DantaThe Maya world's largest pyramid.View of the La Danta pyramid (El Mirador) from the summit of Temple 1 in Nakbe. Named after the powerful animal, the tapir, La Danta is the most voluminous pyramid in the Maya world and rises over 70 meters (230 feet) above the forest floor. Click here to explore interactive QuickTimeVR 360 panorama from La Danta pyramid's summitLearn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Nakbe
properties.description: NakbeNakbe, "Next to the Road"The structures found in Nakbe illustrate the development of monumental construction and architecture among the Maya. Nakbe exists as one of the oldest cities in the Mirador area.Learn more about MiradorFly closer: 4 more points of interestFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Benson Group Structure
properties.description: NakbeBenson Group StructureThe Benson Group is a Late Classic residential group.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Codex Group Structure
properties.description: NakbeCodex Group StructureThe Codex Group is a residential community from the Late Preclassic. This area is the source of the famous Codex pottery, and was home to many accomplished artists. Unfortunately, this Group has seen vast amounts of looting. Most complete examples of Codex pottery resides in private collections.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Codex Group Looter's Trenches
properties.description: NakbeCodex Group Looter's TrenchesThe looting of Maya structures, although curtailed by the presence of guards, continues to pose a significant threat to Mirador’s archaeological integrity.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Kan Causeway
properties.description: NakbeKan CausewayHundreds of miles of Maya Causeways (Sakbe) 'super highways' cross the Mirador Basin connecting all major cities.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Balakbal
properties.description: BalakbalBalakbalThe archaeological site of Balakbal is located inside the Calakmal Biosphere Reserve. A map and a detailed description of the site were published in 1943 by Ruppert and Denison. Structure V, looking south along the passage connecting north and south rooms; Stela 2 is on the left (Ruppert and Denison, 1943, pl 16.d.)(Photo and Text Credits: FAMSI.)Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Calakmul
properties.description: CalakmulCalakmulCalakmul is one of the largest known Maya sites in the world. Located 30 kilometres from the Guatemalan border amidst the high forests of southern Campeche province, Calakmul once rivaled the great Tikal for supremacy of the Maya Empire. It seems certain that Calakmul was a military power during the Late Classic period. The archaeological site covers an area of about 70 square kilometres and has more than six thousand structures, each displaying astonishingly advanced masonry. Unfortunately, most of these structures are now covered by jungle, and few have been restored.Learn more about CalakmulFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Uxul
properties.description: UxulUxulUxul was discovered during the last week of the third expedition of the Carnegie Institution (South of Campeche, near the border of Northern Guatemala) in April 1943. Rupert and Denison noted the existence of fifteen Stelas and six Alters on the site (Rupert and Denison 1943.) In 2000, a segment of Sacbe(Causeway) of 5m (16.5ft) wide and 1m (3.3ft) high was found in the northern part of the site. Perhaps this Causeway connects Calakmul with El Mirador along a 38km (23.5 miles) route. (Map Credit: Carnegie Institution of Washington, D.C)Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Tintal
properties.description: TintalLooter's Trench, TintalTintal is one of the most heavily plundered sites in the Mirador area. Over 2,500 looting trenches mark this site (an average of three trenches per structure). This a major site with pyramidal buildings, palaces, quarries, and canals. Despite extensive looting, many important archaeological findings have occured in Tintal. Many artifacts from Tintal can be seen at the Carlos F. Novella Museum.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Paixban
properties.description: PaixbanPaixbanBorder marker near Paixban.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Wakna
properties.description: WaknaLooted Tomb, WaknaWakna is home to several large pyramids and an E Group. The E Group's large and well preserved observatory, used for the observation of the summer solstice, the equinox, and the winter solstice, is one aspect that defines this site. Wakna has seen some plundering, which has left several burials exposed.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: La Muralla
properties.description: La MurallaLa MurallaA settlement dating to the Late Classic period, La Muralla is named for a large masonry wall that previously displayed a number of stucco busts of what we suppose to be the ancient kings of the Mirador Basin. Unfortunately, looters have removed all of them and all that remains to remind us of this ancient granduer are the empty niches.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: La Florida
properties.description: La FloridaStructure 1, La FloridaLa Florida is a residential group that experienced its largest occupation during the Classic period. One of the unique characteristics of La Florida is the presence of vaulted masonry architectural construction. Structure 1 is a Late Classic palatial building located in the La Ceiba Group of La Florida.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Xulnal
properties.description: XulnalAltar Stone, XulnalXulnal is one of the Mirador's smaller sites. Despite its proximity to Carmelita, the site is exceptionally well preserved. This site dates from the Middle (1000 - 350 B.C) and Late (350 B.C. - 150 A.D.) Preclassic, and is the only major site that has a permanent water supply.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: Naachtun
properties.description: NaachtunNaachtunThe ancient Maya city of Naachtun is still one of the most remote sites in the Yucatan peninsula, and one of the least known of all major Classic Maya centres. The site was re-discovered in 1922 by Sylvanus Morley, who named it Naachtun,"Distant Stone" because of its inaccessibility. Sadly, however, even though Naachtun is extremely isolated, most of the major mounds have been pitted and trenched by looters. Photo and Text Credits: The Naachtun Archeological ProjectLearn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund

properties.name: El Porvenir
properties.description: El PorvenirEl PorvenirEl Provenir is an extensive site dating the Late Classic period that contains a pyramid almost as large as Temple II at Tikal. Heavily looted over the past two decades, evidence indicates that several pieces of the rare Codex Style pottery vases of the Late Classic period may have come from El Porvenir. As with many sites in the zone, El Provenir was also an important Preclassic settlement, and its location between the collasul sites of El Mirador and Tintal could contribute to future research into understanding the regional social network.Learn more about MiradorFoundation for Anthropological Researchand Environmental Studies (FARES)© 2007 Global Heritage Fund
